awd_titl_txt: 2022 Salt and Water Stress in Plants GRC and GRS
awd_abstract_narration:
The greatest challenge to human society in the next 50 years will be to develop a fully sustainable society.  Above and beyond urban or industrial use, agriculture is the largest consumer of land and water.  How can plant biology address these existential problems?  One has only to look back, a little over 50 years, to see that the coincidence of changes in farm management practices and plant breeding led to the Green Revolution.  Through simple changes in plant architecture, farmers were better able to take advantage of past innovations in the production of synthetic fertilizers.  These changes are thought to have saved over a billion lives and reduced the rate of deforestation.  The next Green Revolution will require innovations that go beyond these simple solutions.  Increasing yields in an ecologically conscientious manner will involve interdisciplinary teams including basic scientists, breeders, synthetic biologists, and agronomists.  The goal of the Gordon Research Conference on Salt and Water Stress in Plants is to foster sharing of the latest research in these areas and provide fertile grounds to spawn the next game-changing innovations in plant science that will make a “green”-Green Revolution possible.

The 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Salt and Water Stress in Plants will bring together researchers endeavoring to discover the mechanistic basis of stress tolerance in plants at different scales of organization.  The program represents an acknowledgement of the holistic nature of plant-environmental interactions and the need to integrate research topics that span molecular, cellular, developmental, ecological and global scales.  The program will focus on salinity and other water-associated stresses, and will now also include pioneering work that examines the interface between these stresses and the biotic realm.  Presentations will highlight the power of model systems, tackle evolutionary questions spanning species boundaries, and examine the nexus between basic and applied research using globally relevant crops.  Through this interdisciplinary forum, we hope to pool together researchers that are answering the most compelling scientific questions with the broadest impact.  The bulk of the GRC will comprise 20-minute presentations of unpublished research and 10-minute discussion periods. Although the core of the program is established, nearly half of the talks will be selected from submitted abstracts to air the most recent discoveries and provide opportunities for younger and rising trainees. The program includes poster sessions and free time to enhance idea exchange and networking. The GRS pre-meeting is organized by trainees and focused on multi-disciplinary research topics that explore plant diversity, genomics, integrative physiology and field-relevant research.  The conference will support broader participation through targeted travel awards to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows interested in pursuing plant research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Salt and Water Stress in Plants took place May 22 - 27, 2022 in Les Diablerets Conference Center, Switzerland together with a Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) that preceded the main conference (May 21 - 22). The GRC brought together researchers endeavoring to discover the mechanistic basis of stress tolerance in plants at different scales of organization.  Our program represented an acknowledgement of the holistic nature of plant-environmental interactions and the need to integrate research topics that span molecular, cellular, developmental, ecological and global scales.  The program focused on salinity and other water-associated stresses, and for the first time also included pioneering work that examines the interface between these stresses and the biotic realm.  Presentations highlighted the power of model systems, tackled evolutionary questions spanning species boundaries, and examined the nexus between basic and applied research using globally relevant crops.  Through this interdisciplinary forum, we were able to unite researchers that are answering the most compelling scientific questions with the broadest impact.  

 

The primary Intellectual Merit of the GRS and GRC was the exchange of scientific ideas and the fostering of interactions that can help alleviate critical challenges to global food security associated with salt and extremes in water availability.  The bulk of the GRC comprised 20-minute presentations of unpublished research and 10-minute discussion periods. Although the core of the program was established before abstracts were submitted for consideration, nearly half of the talks will be selected from submitted abstracts to air the most recent discoveries and provide opportunities for younger and rising trainees to present their work. The program included poster sessions and free time to enhance idea exchange and networking. The GRS pre-meeting was organized by trainees and focused on multi-disciplinary research topics that explored plant diversity, genomics, integrative physiology and field-relevant research.  The meeting venue provided an intimate, non-urban and fairly isolated setting to minimize distractions and maximize participant interaction. To promote open discussion of cutting-edge research, the GRC and GRS are officially ?off-the-record?, with no abstracts or proceedings published before, during, or after the conference.

 

The Salt and Water Stress of Plants GRC has a reputation for inclusion of early career scientists. In 2022, 48% of the invited speakers were junior researchers providing many opportunities for senior and new investigators to interact with trainees during the conference. The GRC program included 27 female participants (22 as speakers, 6 as discussion leaders) out of 52 total invited participants.  Invited conference participants truly represent a global perspective on this important research area with 19 countries represented including those of Australia, Africa, East and Southeast Asia and Europe.  To ensure that the pool of conference participants represented the full diversity of the community, we targeted meeting invitations to plant-research related REU programs and the Diversify Plant Science list of researchers.  The conference was advertised at organizations such as SACNAS (Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science), ASPB (American Society of Plant Biologists) and AAAS. The meeting location had facilities to provide access to persons with disabilities and to enable child-care.  We also requested funding to provide full support to 4 post-REU graduate students and partial support for 10 US junior researchers to attend the 2022 GRC and GRS. Supported individuals were selected by GRC co-chairs Jos? Dinneny and Christa Testerink and GRS co-chairs Stephanie Klein and Abdeljalil Elhabti based on abstract submissions. The funding was leveraged to enhance the participation of eligible graduate students, postdocs and early-career faculty who are likely future leaders of multi-disciplinary plant science.
